The Black Student Union
The Student Council's decision to reject the Black Student
Union's charter was predictable. For all intents and purposes, we
could have written this editorial last week. Council members,judging
by the past meeting, have exceptional skill in parliamentary procedure, analysis of "precedents" and the general, empty game of
"student government." However, they have confirmed their inability
to address substantive issues as well as their lack of foresight.
Forget, for one moment, the "Games Student Legislators Play."
Instead, let us consider the value of a Black Student Union at Hopkins
and the reasons why such an organization merits University support - support which they• seemed to have from Univeristy officals when
they organized last spring.
The Hopkins Admissions office continually bewails its inability
to attract black students to Hopkins. The reason is obvious - - in a
semi-Southern City and in a predominantly white university, the
prospective black student must feel that he is entering an alien
situation The Black Student Union, as an officially recognized and
supported organization, could have made giant strides in letting
prospective black students know that they would have somewhere to
turn once they arrived at Homewood - - in the same way that some
Jewish students turn to the J.S.A., in the same way that middle-class
whites invariably make most of their acquaintances with people from
the same background.
The Black Student Union also could have opened avenues of
communication with the official university, letting administrators and
academic deans know about reforms or programs which would be
relevant to the black students as well as their white counterparts.
Members of theSouncil, and others who were present at the
meeting, seemed to unanimously applaud the goals of the Black
Student Union, particularly in relation to BSU help in recruiting black
students.
Obviously, the Council would like to see the BSU continue in
these efforts. We feel that this is somewhat akin to the Council having
its proverbial cake and eating it too. Though we reject any implication
that the SC was bigoted or "racist" in its decision, we would suggest
that this attitude, as innocent as it may be, points up the reason for
black resentment against whites in America today.
Other colleges and universities have debated the same "discriminatory" membership clause in black student group charters.Overwhelmingly, they have decided that the special nature and purpose of
black student groups overrides the importance of parliamentary
haggling. Notably, the University of Pennsylvania student government
tackled the same question and decided not only to grant a charter to
the U. of P. black students, but to fund them with $2,100. Even
Goucher has approved the charter of their black students' group.
In the past, we have urged the Student Council to deal with
relevant, weighty issues instead of traditional trivia. We retract that
suggestion. We do not feel the Council is capable of dealing with such
issues. If one checks the recent history of the Council, this will be
borne out. After "urging" from the News-Letter, the Council
undertook the writing of a Student Bill of Rights (suggested by the
News-Letter) which failed; it also sought to establish the Free
University, (also suggested at a Council meeting by the News-Letter)
which has been one of their few substantial successes.
If it were not for the question of funds, we would have advised
the Black Student Union to completely ignore the Student Council
and to operate independently, which it appears it will now do
anyway. We would recommend this approach to students in the
future.

The Black Student Union
The Student Council's decision to reject the Black Student
Union's charter was predictable. For all intents and purposes, we
could have written this editorial last week. Council members,judging
by the past meeting, have exceptional skill in parliamentary procedure, analysis of "precedents" and the general, empty game of
"student government." However, they have confirmed their inability
to address substantive issues as well as their lack of foresight.
Forget, for one moment, the "Games Student Legislators Play."
Instead, let us consider the value of a Black Student Union at Hopkins
and the reasons why such an organization merits University support - support which they• seemed to have from Univeristy officals when
they organized last spring.
The Hopkins Admissions office continually bewails its inability
to attract black students to Hopkins. The reason is obvious - - in a
semi-Southern City and in a predominantly white university, the
prospective black student must feel that he is entering an alien
situation The Black Student Union, as an officially recognized and
supported organization, could have made giant strides in letting
prospective black students know that they would have somewhere to
turn once they arrived at Homewood - - in the same way that some
Jewish students turn to the J.S.A., in the same way that middle-class
whites invariably make most of their acquaintances with people from
the same background.
The Black Student Union also could have opened avenues of
communication with the official university, letting administrators and
academic deans know about reforms or programs which would be
relevant to the black students as well as their white counterparts.
Members of theSouncil, and others who were present at the
meeting, seemed to unanimously applaud the goals of the Black
Student Union, particularly in relation to BSU help in recruiting black
students.
Obviously, the Council would like to see the BSU continue in
these efforts. We feel that this is somewhat akin to the Council having
its proverbial cake and eating it too. Though we reject any implication
that the SC was bigoted or "racist" in its decision, we would suggest
that this attitude, as innocent as it may be, points up the reason for
black resentment against whites in America today.
Other colleges and universities have debated the same "discriminatory" membership clause in black student group charters.Overwhelmingly, they have decided that the special nature and purpose of
black student groups overrides the importance of parliamentary
haggling. Notably, the University of Pennsylvania student government
tackled the same question and decided not only to grant a charter to
the U. of P. black students, but to fund them with $2,100. Even
Goucher has approved the charter of their black students' group.
In the past, we have urged the Student Council to deal with
relevant, weighty issues instead of traditional trivia. We retract that
suggestion. We do not feel the Council is capable of dealing with such
issues. If one checks the recent history of the Council, this will be
borne out. After "urging" from the News-Letter, the Council
undertook the writing of a Student Bill of Rights (suggested by the
News-Letter) which failed; it also sought to establish the Free
University, (also suggested at a Council meeting by the News-Letter)
which has been one of their few substantial successes.
If it were not for the question of funds, we would have advised
the Black Student Union to completely ignore the Student Council
and to operate independently, which it appears it will now do
anyway. We would recommend this approach to students in the
future.
